repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Multisectoral HIV/AIDS Control
            and Orphans Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Multisectoral HIV/AIDS
            Control and Orphans Project (MAOP) for Burundi were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: adoption of a fast track preparatory process has
            hidden costs that cannot be discounted. The extensive effort
            needed over the first few years of the project period
            essentially to complete preparation of core inputs required
            for actual project execution significantly slowed
            implementation and disbursements and ultimately contributed
            to the need to extend the MAOP closing date by almost two
            years. The risks to implementation from capacity weaknesses,
            particularly pervasive shortages of skilled professionals,
            can be and indeed were in Burundi significantly
            underestimated during project preparation. These shortages
            presented major obstacles to effective, efficient project
            implementation. Tackling major, widespread human resource
            constraints may be best done cross-sectorally rather than on
            a sector-by-sector basis since the underlying dynamics of
            low morale and high turnover among civil servants tend to be
            common across public sector entities. High turnover of Bank
            Task Team Leaders (TTLs) presents a major obstacle smooth
            project implementation. The five TTLs over the MAOP life led
            to serious shortfalls in project performance, monitoring,
            and reporting. Continuity of Bank project leadership,
            particularly in challenging operational environments is
            essential. Similarly, having two executive secretaries at
            the National AIDS Council (NAC) was disruptive. In such
            circumstances, increased attention must also be given to
            identifying alternative approaches to attract and retain
            project managers in executing agencies.

Burundi - Multisectoral HIV/AIDS Control and
            Orphans Project

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Projet Multisectoriel pour la
            Lutte contre le VIH/SIDA et l'Appui aux Orphelins :
            plan de gestion des dechets biomedicaux

abstracts.cdata!:
The analysis of management waste systems
            in medical institutions in Burundi, renders the following
            findings: in mostly all institutions, medical, and
            biomedical waste management is exclusively confined to the
            cleaning staff members; most institutions do have brick
            incinerators, which are not functional due to lack of
            maintenance; there is no awareness on the importance of
            medical waste management within the medical personnel
            (medical wastes are often mixed with regular trash); and, a
            total absence of training prevails for medical waste
            management. Based on the analysis, this biomedical waste
            management plan suggest recommendations as follows.
            Legislation on medical, and biomedical waste management
            needs to be established, implemented, and enforced,
            regulated by waste management committees at the national,
            provincial, and municipal levels, with communal
            participation. In addition, hospitals and health care
            facilities should establish their own medical waste plans in
            compliance with the country's laws, and regulations, in
            order to set a governing institutional framework. Medical
            personnel should be trained in the management of the overall
            medical waste sector, and in addition, training should be
            further provided to staff members in charge of the
            institution's cleaning, and waste management practices.
            Public awareness should be raised, through community
            mobilization, and active participation of civil society, the
            private sector, organizations in general, and policymakers
            in particular, on the adequate management of biomedical
            wastes. Most importantly, electrical incinerators should
            replace existing ones, based on standard sanitary
            regulations, but to be later phased-out, and replaced by new
            waste treatment technologies.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Multisectoral HIV/AIDS Control
            and Orphans Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Multisectoral HIV/AIDS Control and
            Orphans Project will support the national program as set
            forth in its Action Plan for the Struggle Against HIV/AIDS
            for the period 2002-2006, through actions involving in-line
            ministries, civil society, private enterprises, labor
            unions, in addition to women and youth, and nongovernmental
            organizations (NGOs). Through its components, the project
            will: 1) strengthen public sector responsiveness to the
            HIV/AIDS crisis, by supporting the country's control
            strategy, and action plan, targeting assistance to
            respective sectors. Selected activities will be financed,
            particularly for implementing national medical waste
            management plan, covering as well, prevention, mitigation,
            and capacity building; 2) increase civil society response to
            prod grassroots organizations, and communities in the fight
            against the epidemic. Capacity building, and initiatives by
            the private sector will be targeted at implementing
            prevention strategies for employees, and families, to be
            assessed against an eligibility criteria, whereas funds will
            be granted to associations and private enterprises,
            including NGOs, and community-based organizations; 3)
            support the placement of orphans with their extended
            families, or when necessary with unrelated families. Orphans
            shall be provided with scholarships for primary education,
            and vocational training, while the economic, and nutritional
            well being of families in care will be strengthened through
            investments, and income generating activities; 4) reinforce
            the capacity of public, and private agencies in the
            formulation, and implementation of the epidemic's
            control, by strengthening coordination, monitoring and
            evaluation criteria; and, 5) ensure project coordination, by
            financing operational costs, technical assistance, and
            equipment supply as needed.
